A fifteenth part.
A fifteenth.
A green crystalline substance formed by the union of quinone with hydroquinone, or as an intermediate product in the oxidation of hydroquinone or the reduction of quinone.
Quinine.
An interval of a fifth; also, a part sung with such intervals.
entry.q: He sang . . . a loudquynyble.

entry.def: Pertaining to, derived from, or connected with, quinine and related compounds; specifically, designating a nonnitrogenous acid obtained from cinchona bark, coffee, beans, etc., as a white crystalline substance.
An uncrystallizable alkaloid obtained by the action of heat from quinine, with which it is isomeric.

An alkaloid isomeric with, and resembling, quinine, found in certain species of cinchona, from which it is extracted as a bitter white crystalline substance; conchinine. It is used somewhat as a febrifuge.

entry.ety: F. (cf. Sp. quinina), fr. Sp. quina, or quinaquina, Peruvian bark, fr. Peruv. kina quina, bark. Cf. Kinic
entry.def: An alkaloid extracted from the bark of several species of cinchona (esp. Cinchona Calisaya) as a bitter white crystalline substance, C20H24N2O2. Hence, by extension Med, any of the salts of this alkaloid, as the acetate, chloride, sulphate, etc., employed as a febrifuge or antiperiodic. Called also quinia quinina, etc.
Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid obtained as a yellow crystalline substance by the oxidation of quinine.
See Cinchonism.
A yellow crystalline substance produced artificially. It is isomeric with alizarin.
any one of a series of nitrogenous bases, certain of which are used as antipyretics.
The California salmon (Oncorhynchus choicha); -- called also chouicha king salmon chinnook salmon, and Sacramento salmon. It is of great commercial importance.
The seeds of a kind of goosewort (Chenopodium Quinoa), used in Chili and Peru for making porridge or cakes; also, food thus made.
A hypothetical radical of quinine and related alkaloids.
A brownish resinous substance obtained as a by-product in the treatment of cinchona bark. It consists of a mixture of several alkaloids.

A nitrogenous base, C9H7N obtained as a pungent colorless liquid by the distillation of alkaloids, bones, coal tar, etc. It the nucleus of many organic bodies, especially of certain alkaloids and related substances; hence, by extension, any one of the series of alkaloidal bases of which quinoline proper is the type.
One who is versed in quinology.
The science which treats of the cultivation of the cinchona, and of its use in medicine.

A crystalline substance, C6H4O2called also benzoketone), first obtained by the oxidation of quinic acid and regarded as a double ketone; also, by extension, any one of the series of which quinone proper is the type.
Pertaining to, or designating, a crystalline acid obtained from some varieties of cinchona bark.

entry.ety: NL. quina nova the tree Cosmibuena magnifolia, whose bark yields quinovin
entry.def: An amorphous bitter glucoside derived from cinchona and other barks. Called also quinova bitter, and quinova.
Any one of a series of complex nitrogenous bases obtained by the union of certain aniline derivatives with glyoxal or with certain ketones.
The hypothetical radical of certain quinone derivatives related to rhodizonic acid.
A radical of which quinone is the hydride, analogous to phenyl.

cs.cd: the Sunday which is the fiftieth day before Easter, both days being included in the reckoning; -- called also Shrove Sunday.

entry.ety: L., fr. quinquagesimus the fiftieth, akin to quinquaginta fifty, quinque five. See Five
entry.def: Fiftieth.

entry.ety: L. quinquanqulus; quinque five + angulus ad angle: cf. F. quinquangulaire
entry.def: Having five angles or corners.
Relating to the five articles or points; as, the quinquarticular controversy between Arminians and Calvinists.

entries.entry:
Quin"que-. L. quinque five. See Five
A combining form meaning five five times fivefold; as, quinquefid, five-cleft; quinquedentate, five-toothed.

entry.def: Having five angles; quinquangular.
Five-toothed; as, a quinquedentate leaf.

entry.ety: From L. quinque five: cf. F. quinquéfarié. Cf. Bifarious
entry.def: Arranged in five vertical rows; pentastichous.

entry.ety: Quique- + the root of L. findere to cleave: cf. F. quinquéfide
entry.def: Sharply cut about halfway to the middle or base into five segments; as, a quinquefid leaf or corolla.

entry.ety: Quinque- + foliate -ated: cf. F. quinquéfolié, L. quinquefolius
entry.def: Having five leaves or leaflets.
Having five leaflets.
Consisting of five letters.
Cut less than halfway into portions, usually somewhat rounded; five-lobed; as, a quinquelobate leaf or corolla.
Same as Quinquelobate.
Having five cells or loculi; five-celled; as, a quinquelocular pericarp.
Having five nerves; -- said of a leaf with five nearly equal nerves or ribs rising from the end of the petiole.
Public games celebrated every five years.

entry.ety: L. quinquennalis and quinquennis; quinque five + annus year. See Five and cf. Biennial
entry.def: Occurring once in five years, or at the end of every five years; also, lasting five years. A quinquennial event.
Space of five years.

entry.ety: L. quinquepartitus; quinque five + partitus, p. p. of partire to divide: cf. F. quinquépartite

sn.def: Consisting of five parts.
Divided into five parts almost to the base.

entry.ety: L. quinqueremis; quinque five + remus an oar: cf. F. quinquérème
entry.def: A galley having five benches or banks of oars; as, an Athenian quinquereme .
A word of five syllables.

entry.ety: Quinque- + valve valvular: cf. F. quinquévalve
entry.def: Having five valves, as a pericarp.

entries.entry: Quin"que*vir Quin"que*vir n.; pl; E. Quinquevirs #, L. Quinqueviri #. L., fr. quinque Five + vir man Bot. Antiq One of five commissioners appointed for some special object.

entry.def: Peruvian bark.

entry.ety: Quinque- + L. valens -entis, p. pr. See Valence
entry.def: Same as Pentavalent.

entry.ety: Contr. fr. squinancy, F. esquinancie, L. cynanche a sort of sore throat, Gr. � sore throat, dog quinsy, fr. � dog + � to choke; cf. also L. synanche sore throat, Gr. �. Cf. Hound Anger, and Cynanche
entry.def: An inflammation of the throat, or parts adjacent, especially of the fauces or tonsils, attended by considerable swelling, painful and impeded deglutition, and accompanied by inflammatory fever. It sometimes creates danger of suffocation; -- called also squinancy, and squinzey.

entry.ety: F. quinte, fr. L. quintus quinta, the fifth, quinque five. See Five

sn.def: A set or sequence of five, as in piquet.
The interval of a fifth.
one of a set of quintuplets.

entry.note: ☞ A common form in the Middle Ages was an upright post, on the top of which turned a crosspiece, having on one end a broad board, and on the other a sand bag. The endeavor was to strike the board with the lance while riding under, and get away without being hit by the sand bag. “But a quintain, a mere lifeless block.”
entry.ety: F. quintaine, LL. quintana; cf. W. chwintan a kind of hymeneal game
entry.def: An object to be tilted at; -- called also quintel.

entry.ety: F., fr. Sp. quintal, fr. Ar. qintar a weight of 100 lbs., prob. fr. L. centenarius consisting of a hundred, fr. centeni a hundred each, fr. centum a hundred. See Hundred, and cf. Kentle

sn.def: A hundredweight, either 112 or 100 pounds, according to the scale used. Cf. Cental.
A metric measure of weight, being 100,000 grams, or 100 kilograms, equal to 220.46 pounds avoirdupois.

entry.ety: L. quintanus, fr. quintus fifth, quinque five. See Five
entry.def: Occurring as the fifth, after four others also, occurring every fifth day, reckoning inclusively; as, a quintan fever.

def2.def: An intermittent fever which returns every fifth day, reckoning inclusively, or in which the intermission lasts three days.

entry.def: See Quintain.

entry.note: ☞ The ancient Greeks recognized four elements, fire, air, water, and earth. The Pythagoreans added a fifth and called it nether, the fifth essence, which they said flew upward at creation and out of it the stars were made. The alchemists sometimes considered alcohol, or the ferment oils, as the fifth essence.
entry.ety: F., fr. L. quinta essentia fifth essence. See Quint, and Essence

sn.def: The fifth or last and highest essence or power in a natural body. See Ferment oils, under Ferment.
Hence: An extract from anything, containing its rarest virtue, or most subtle and essential constituent in a small quantity; pure or concentrated essence.
sn.q: Let there be light, said God; and forthwith light Ethereal, first of things, quintessence pure, Sprung from the deep.

sn.def: The most characteristic form or most perfect example of some type of object.

entry.def: To distil or extract as a quintessence; to reduce to a quintessence.
entry.q: Truthquintessencedand raised to the highest power.

entry.def: Of the nature of a quintessence; purest; most characteristic.
entry.q: Quintessentialextract of mediocrity.

entry.ety: It. quintetto, dim. of quinto the fifth, a fifth part, from L. quintus the fifth: cf. F. quintette. See Quint
entry.def: A composition for five voices or instruments; also, the set of five persons who sing or play five-part music.

entry.ety: L. quintus fifth, fr. quinque five
entry.def: Of the fifth degree or order.

def2.def: A quantic of the fifth degree. See Quantic.

entry.ety: F. quintil aspect, fr. L. quintus the fifth
entry.def: The aspect of planets when separated the fifth part of the zodiac, or 72°.

entry.ety: Formed fr. L. quintus the fifth, after the analogy of million: cf. F. quintillion. See Quint
entry.def: According to the French notation, which is used on the Continent and in America, the cube of a million, or a unit with eighteen ciphers annexed; according to the English notation, a number produced by involving a million to the fifth power, or a unit with thirty ciphers annexed. See the Note under Numeration.
See Quintain.

entry.ety: L. quintus the fifth: cf. F. quintine
entry.def: The embryonic sac of an ovule, sometimes regarded as an innermost fifth integument. Cf. Quartine, and Tercine.
A group of five notes to be played or sung in the time of four of the same species.

entry.ety: Sp. quinteron the off-spring of a quadroon and a white
entry.def: The off-spring of an octoroon and a white person.

cs.cd: a time having five beats in a measure. It is seldom used.

entry.ety: L. quintus fifth: cf. F. quintuple, L. quintuplex. Cf. Quadruple
entry.def: Multiplied by five; increased to five times the amount; fivefold.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quintupled; p. pr. & vb. n. Quintupling
entry.def: To make fivefold, or five times as much or many.

sn.def: A collection or combination of five of a kind.
Five children born in the same labor.
A group of five connected notes; a turn of five notes.
A cycle having five crank shafts and adapted for five riders, all of whom can assist in the propulsion.

entry.def: five children born from one mother in a single pregnancy.
The same as Quinquenerved.

entry.ety: F., from quinze fifteen, L. quindecim. See Fifteen
entry.def: The fifteenth day after a feast day, including both in the reckoning.
A game at cards in which the object is to make fifteen points.

entry.ety: Cf. W. chwip a quick flirt or turn, chwipio to whip, to move briskly, and E. whip. Cf. Quib Quibble

sn.def: A smart, sarcastic turn or jest; a taunt; a severe retort; a gibe.
sn.q: Quips, and cranks, and wanton wiles.
He was full of joke and jest, But all his merry quips are o'er.

sn.def: A short humorous or witty comment or observation, usually spontaneously formed in response to a prior comment.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quipped; p. pr. & vb. n. Quipping
entry.def: To taunt; to treat with quips.
entry.q: The more he laughs, and does her closely quip.

entry.def: To scoff; to use taunts.
Same as Quipu.
A person who frequently makes quips.

entries.entry:
Qui"pu Qui"pu n.; pl.Quipus #. Peruv. quipu a knot A contrivance employed by the ancient Peruvians, Mexicans, etc., as a substitute for writing and figures, consisting of a main cord, from which hung at certain distances smaller cords of various colors, each having a special meaning, as silver, gold, corn, soldiers. etc. Single, double, and triple knots were tied in the smaller cords, representing definite numbers. It was chiefly used for arithmetical purposes, and to register important facts and events.
quipo
Tylor. The mysterious science of the quipus . . . supplied the Peruvians with the means of communicating their ideas to one another, and of transmitting them to future generations.

entry.def: Leather softened by boiling so as to take any required shape. Upon drying, it becomes exceedingly hard, and hence was formerly used for armor.
entry.q: His jambeux were ofquyrboilly.

entry.def: See Choir.
entry.q: A quire of such enticing birds.

entry.def: To sing in concert.

entry.ety: OE. quaer quair, OF. quayer cayer caïer, F. cahier, a book of loose sheets, a quarter of a quire, LL. quaternus quaternum, sheets of paper packed together, properly, four together, fr. L. quaterni four each, by fours, quattuor four. See Four and cf. Cahier
entry.def: A collection of twenty-four sheets of paper of the same size and quality, unfolded or having a single fold; one twentieth of a ream.

entry.ety: L. Quirinalis, fr. Quirinus, a name of Romulus
entry.def: Of, pertaining to, or designating, the hill Collis Quirinalis, now Monte Quirinaleone of the seven hills of Rome), or a modern royal place situated upon it. Also used substantively.
A chorister. See Chorister.

entry.ety: L. quiritatio, fr. quiritare to raise a plaintive cry, v. freq. fr. queri to complain
entry.def: A crying for help.
One of the Quirites.

entry.note: ☞ After the Sabines and Romans had united themselves into one community, under Romulus, the name of Quirites was taken in addition to that of Romani, the Romans calling themselves in a civil capacity Quirites, while in a political and military capacity they retained the name of Romani.
entry.ety: L., fr. Cures, a Sabine town
entry.def: Roman citizens.

cs.cd: a bead between two quirks.

entry.ety: Cf. W. chwiori to turn briskly, or E. queer

sn.def: A sudden turn; a starting from the point or line; hence, an artful evasion or subterfuge; a shift; a quibble; as, the quirks of a pettifogger.
sn.q: Somequirkor . . . evasion.
We ground the justification of our nonconformity on dark subtilties and intricate quirks.

sn.def: A fit or turn; a short paroxysm; a caprice.
sn.q: Quirksof joy and grief.

sn.def: A smart retort; a quibble; a shallow conceit.
sn.q: Some odd quirks and remnants of wit.

sn.def: An irregular air; as, light quirks of music.
A piece of ground taken out of any regular ground plot or floor, so as to make a court, yard, etc.; -- sometimes written quink.
A small channel, deeply recessed in proportion to its width, used to insulate and give relief to a convex rounded molding.

entry.def: Having, or formed with, a quirk or quirks.
Consisting of quirks; resembling a quirk.
Full of quirks; tricky; as, a quirky lawyer.
See Querl.
The Indian ferret.
A rawhide whip plaited with two thongs of buffalo hide.
See Cuish.
Any one of numerous species of small passerine birds native of tropical America. See Banana quit, under Banana, and Guitguit.

entry.note: ☞ This word is sometimes used in the form quits, colloquially; as, to be quits with one, that is, to have made mutual satisfaction of demands with him; to be even with him; hence, as an exclamation: Quits! we are even, or on equal terms. “To cry quits with the commons in their complaints.”
entry.ety: OE. quite, OF. quite, F. quitte. See Quit v. Quiet
entry.def: Released from obligation, charge, penalty, etc.; free; clear; absolved; acquitted.
entry.q: The owner of the ox shall be quit.

cs.cd: to pay; to reimburse.
to make even; to clear mutually from demands.

entry.usage: Quit Leave. Leave is a general term, signifying merely an act of departure; quit implies a going without intention of return, a final and absolute abandonment.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quit or Quitted; p. pr. & vb. n. Quitting
entry.ety: OE. quiten, OF. quiter quitier cuitier, F. quitter, to acquit, quit, LL. quietare, fr. L. quietare to calm, to quiet, fr. quietus quiet. See Quiet a., and cf. Quit a. Quite Acquit Requite

sn.def: To set at rest; to free, as from anything harmful or oppressive; to relieve; to clear; to liberate.
sn.q: To quit you of this fear, you have already looked Death in the face; what have you found so terrible in it?

sn.def: To release from obligation, accusation, penalty, or the like; to absolve; to acquit.
sn.q: There may no gold them quyte.
God will relent, and quit thee all his debt.

sn.def: To discharge, as an obligation or duty; to meet and satisfy, as a claim or debt; to make payment for or of; to requite; to repay.
sn.q: The blissful martyr quyte you your meed.
Enkindle all the sparks of nature To quit this horrid act.
Before that judge that quits each soul his hire.

sn.def: To meet the claims upon, or expectations entertained of; to conduct; to acquit; -- used reflexively.
sn.q: Be strong, and quit yourselves like men.
Samson hath quit himself Like Samson.

sn.def: To carry through; to go through to the end.
sn.q: Never worthy prince a day did quit With greater hazard and with more renown.

sn.def: To have done with; to cease from; to stop; hence, to depart from; to leave; to forsake; as, to quit work; to quit the place; to quit jesting.
sn.q: Such a superficial way of examining is to quit truth for appearance.
Does not the earth quit scores with all the elements in the noble fruits that issue from it?
sn.syn: To leave; relinquish; resign; abandon; forsake; surrender; discharge; requite.

entry.def: To go away; to depart; to stop doing a thing; to cease.

sn.def: Same as Quitch grass.
Figuratively: A vice; a taint; an evil.
sn.q: To pick the vicious quitch Of blood and custom wholly out of him.

entries.entry:
Quitch" grass` kwĭch" grȧs`. Properly quick grass, being probably so called from its vigorous growth, or from its tenacity of life. See Quick, and cf. Couch grass
Bot A perennial grass (Agropyrum repens) having long running rootstalks, by which it spreads rapidly and pertinaciously, and so becomes a troublesome weed. Also called couch grass quack grass quick grass twitch grass. See Illustration in Appendix.

entry.def: A release or relinquishment of a claim; a deed of release; an instrument by which some right, title, interest, or claim, which one person has, or is supposed to have, in or to an estate held by himself or another, is released or relinquished, the grantor generally covenanting only against persons who claim under himself.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quitclaimed kwĭt"klāmd`; p. pr. & vb. n. Quitclaiming
entry.def: To release or relinquish a claim to; to release a claim to by deed, without covenants of warranty against adverse and paramount titles.
See Quit.

entry.ety: F. quitte discharged, free, clear; cf. OF. quitement freely, frankly, entirely. See Quit a.

sn.def: Completely; wholly; entirely; totally; perfectly; as, the work is not quite done; the object is quite accomplished; to be quite mistaken.
sn.q: Man shall not quite be lost, but saved who will.
The same actions may be aimed at different ends, and arise from quite contrary principles.

sn.def: To a great extent or degree; very; very much; considerably.
sn.q: Quiteamusing.
He really looks quite concerned.
The island stretches along the land and is quite close to it.

entry.def: Quite.

entry.note: ☞ In some of the United States a fee-farm rent is so termed.
entry.def: A rent reserved in grants of land, by the payment of which the tenant is quit from other service.
See the Note under Quit a.
Capable of being quitted.
Return; requital; quittance.

entry.ety: OE. quitaunce, OF. quitance, F. quittance. See Quit v. t.

sn.def: Discharge from a debt or an obligation; acquittance.
sn.q: Omittance is no quittance.

sn.def: Recompense; return; repayment.

entry.def: To repay; to requite.

sn.def: One who quits.
A deliverer.

entry.def: A chronic abscess, or fistula of the coronet, in a horse's foot, resulting from inflammation of the tissues investing the coffin bone.
A discharge; an issue.
entry.q: To cleanse the quitture from thy wound.

entry.ety: Akin to AS. cwiferlice anxiously; cf. OD. kuiven kuiveren. Cf. Quaver
entry.def: Nimble; active.
entry.q: A littlequiverfellow.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quivered kwĭv"ẽrd; p. pr. & vb. n. Quivering
entry.def: To shake or move with slight and tremulous motion; to tremble; to quake; to shudder; to shiver.
entry.q: The green leaves quiver with the cooling wind.
And left the limbs still quivering on the ground.

entry.def: The act or state of quivering; a tremor.

entry.ety: OF. cuivre cuevre coivre, LL. cucurum, fr. OHG. chohhāri quiver, receptacle, G. köcher quiver; akin to AS. cocor cocur cocer, D. koker. Cf. Cocker a high shoe
entry.def: A case or sheath for arrows to be carried on the person.
entry.q: Beside him hung his bow And quiver, with three-bolted thunder stored.

sn.def: Furnished with, or carrying, a quiver.
sn.q: Like aquiverednymph with arrows keen.

sn.def: Sheathed, as in a quiver.
sn.q: Whose quills standquiveredat his ear.

entry.def: With quivering motion.

entries.entry:
Qui` vive" Qui` vive"
To be on the qui vive to be on guard; to be watchful and alert, like a sentinel.
k�` v�v". F., fr. qui who + vive, pres. subj. of vivre to live The challenge of a French sentinel, or patrol; -- used like the English challenge: “Who comes there?”

sn.def: Like Don Quixote; romantic to extravagance; prone to pursue unrealizable goals; absurdly chivalric; apt to be deluded. See also quixotism.
sn.q: Feats ofquixoticgallantry.

sn.def: Like the deeds of Don Quixote; ridiculously impractical; unachievable; extravagantly romantic; doomed to failure; as, a quixotic quest.

q.au: Simon Leys (N. Y. Review of Books, June 11, 1998, p. 35)

sn.q: The word “quixotic” . . . has entered the common language, with the meaning “hopelessly naive and idealistic,” “ridiculously impractical,” “doomed to fail.” That this epithet can be used now in an exclusively pejorative sense not only shows that we have ceased to read Cervantes and to understand his character, but more fundamentally it reveals that our culture has drifted away from its spiritual roots.

entry.def: In a quixotic way.

That form of delusion which leads to extravagant and absurd undertakings or sacrifices in obedience to a morbidly romantic ideal of duty or honor, as illustrated by the exploits of Don Quixote in knight-errantry. See quixotic.
Quixotism; visionary schemes.

entry.ety: It is said that Daly, the manager of a Dublin playhouse, laid a wager that a new word of no meaning should be the common talk and puzzle of the city in twenty-four hours. In consequence of this the letters q u i z were chalked by him on all the walls of Dublin, with an effect that won the wager. Perhaps, however, originally a variant of whiz, and formerly the name of a popular game

sn.def: A riddle or obscure question; an enigma; a ridiculous hoax.
One who quizzes others; as, he is a great quiz .
An odd or absurd fellow.
An exercise, or a course of exercises, conducted as a coaching or as an examination.

cs.cd: a small eyeglass.

entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quizzed kwĭzd; p. pr. & vb. n. Quizzing kwĭz"zĭng

sn.def: To puzzle; to banter; to chaff or mock with pretended seriousness of discourse; to make sport of, as by obscure questions.
sn.q: He quizzed unmercifully all the men in the room.

sn.def: To peer at; to eye suspiciously or mockingly.
To instruct in or by a quiz. See Quiz n., 4.

entry.def: To conduct a quiz. See Quiz n., 4.
One who quizzes; a quiz.
Relating to quizzing; given to quizzing; of the nature of a quiz; farcical; sportive.
The act or habit of quizzing.
To throb; to quiver.
A quadrangle or court, as of a prison; hence, a prison.
entry.q: Flogged or whipped inquod.

entry.def: Quoth; said. See Quoth.
entry.q: “Let be,” quod he, “it shall not be.”

entry.def: To put in quod, or prison; to lock up; to jug.
Herring taken and cured or smoked near Quoddy Head, Maine, or near the entrance of Passamaquoddy Bay.

sn.def: A nice point; a subtilty; a debatable point.
sn.q: These are your quodlibets, but no learning.

sn.def: A medley improvised by several performers.

entry.def: One who discusses any subject at pleasure.
Not restricted to a particular subject; discussed for curiosity or entertainment.
See Coif.
See Coiffure.
See Coil.

entry.note: ☞ In stone, the quoins consist of blocks larger than those used in the rest of the building, and cut to dimension. In brickwork, quoins consist of groups or masses of brick laid together, and in a certain imitation of quoins of stone.
entry.cs: Hollow quoin. See under Hollow. Quoin post Canals the post of a lock gate which abuts against the wall.

sn.def: Originally, a solid exterior angle, as of a building; now, commonly, one of the selected pieces of material by which the corner is marked.
A wedgelike piece of stone, wood, metal, or other material, used for various purposes;

sd.def: To support and steady a stone.
To support the breech of a cannon.
To wedge or lock up a form within a chase.
To prevent casks from rolling.

entry.ety: OE. coite; cf. OF. coitier to spur, press, (assumed) LL. coctare, fr. L. coquere coctum, to cook, burn, vex, harass, E. cook, also W. coete� a quoit

sd.def: A flattened ring-shaped piece of iron, to be pitched at a fixed object in play; hence, any heavy flat missile used for the same purpose, as a stone, piece of iron, etc.
A game played with quoits.

sn.def: The discus of the ancients. See Discus.
A cromlech.

entry.def: To throw quoits; to play at quoits.
entry.q: To quoit, to run, and steeds and chariots drive.

entry.def: To throw; to pitch.
imp. of Quake.
A marsupial of Australia Dasyurus macrurus), about the size of a cat.
Having been formerly; former; sometime.
entry.q: This is thequondamking.

entry.def: A person dismissed or ejected from a position.
entry.q: Make themquondams; . . . cast them out of their office.

entry.def: imp. of Quake.
See Quob.

entry.note: ☞ The term arose from the Latin words, Quorum aliquem vestrum . . . unum esse volumusof whom we wish some one of you to be one), which were used in the commission formerly issued to justices of the peace in England, by which commission it was directed that no business of certain kinds should be done without the presence of one or more of certain justices specially designated. Justice of the peace and of the quorum designates a class of justices of the peace in some of the United States.
entry.ety: L., of whom, gen. pl. of qui who, akin to E. who. See the Note below
entry.def: Such a number of the officers or members of any body as is competent by law or constitution to transact business; as, a quorum of the House of Representatives; a constitutional quorum was not present.

entry.ety: LL., fr. L. quotasc. pars), fr. quotus which or what in number, of what number, how many, fr. quot how many, akin to quis qui, who: cf. It. quota a share. See Who

sn.def: A proportional part or share; the share or proportion assigned to each in a division.
sn.q: Quotaof troops and money.

sn.def: a share of effort required to be performed, or a share of resources required to be contributed to some common purpose.

entry.def: Capable or worthy of being quoted; as, a quotable writer; a quotable sentence.

cs.cd: two inverted commas placed at the beginning, and two apostrophes at the end, of a passage quoted from an author in his own words.

sn.def: The act of quoting or citing.
That which is quoted or cited; a part of a book or writing named, repeated, or adduced as evidence or illustration.
The naming or publishing of the current price of stocks, bonds, or any commodity; also, the price named.
Quota; share.
A piece of hollow type metal, lower than type, and measuring two or more pica ems in length and breadth, used in the blank spaces at the beginning and end of chapters, etc.

entry.def: One who makes, or is given to making, quotations.
entry.q: The narrow intellectuals of quotationists.

entry.usage: Quote Cite. To cite was originally to call into court as a witness, etc., and hence denotes bringing forward any thing or person as evidence. Quote usually signifies to reproduce another's words; it is also used to indicate an appeal to some one as an authority, without adducing his exact words.
entry.vmorph: imp. & p. p. Quoted; p. pr. & vb. n. Quoting
entry.ety: OF. quoter, F. coter to letter, number, to quote, LL. quotare to divide into chapters and verses, fr. L. quotus. See Quota

sn.def: To cite, as a passage from some author; to name, repeat, or adduce, as a passage from an author or speaker, by way of authority or illustration; as, to quote a passage from Homer.
To cite a passage from; to name as the authority for a statement or an opinion; as, to quote Shakespeare.
To name the current price of.
To notice; to observe; to examine.
To set down, as in writing.
sn.q: He'squotedfor a most perfidious slave.

entry.def: A note upon an author.
One who quotes the words of another.

entry.ety: AS. cweðan, imp cwæð, pl. cwǣdon; akin to OS. queðan, OHG. quethan quedan, Icel. kveða, Goth. qiþan. √22. Cf. Bequeath
entry.def: Said; spoke; uttered; -- used only in the first and third persons in the past tenses, and always followed by its nominative, the word or words said being the object; as, quoth I quoth he .
entry.q: Let me not live,quothhe.

entry.ety: For quoth 'a, said he, 'a being corrupted from he
entry.def: Indeed; forsooth.
entry.q: To affront the blessed hillside drabs and thieves With mended morals, quotha, -- fine new lives !

entry.ety: OE. cotidian, L. quotidianus, fr. quotidie daily; quotus how many + dies day: cf. OF. cotidien, F. quotidien. See Quota Deity
entry.def: Occurring or returning daily; as, a quotidian fever.
Anything returning daily; especially Med, an intermittent fever or ague which returns every day.

entry.ety: F., fr. L. quoties how often, how many times, fr. quot how many. See Quota

sn.def: The number resulting from the division of one number by another, and showing how often a less number is contained in a greater; thus, the quotient of twelve divided by four is three.
The result of any process inverse to multiplication. See the Note under Multiplication.

entry.ety: L. quotus of what number, quot how many
entry.def: The relation of an object to number.

entry.ety: NL., fr. L. quotus of what number. See Quota
entry.def: Part or proportion; quota.
entry.q: A very smallquotum.

entries.entry:
Quo` war*ran"to Quo` war*ran"to ☞ An information in the nature of a quo warranto is now common as a substitute for the writ. Wharton.
kwō` wŏr*răn"t�. So called from the Law L. words quo warrantoby what authority), in the original Latin form of the writ. See Which, and Warrant
Law A writ brought before a proper tribunal, to inquire by what warrant a person or a corporation acts, or exercises certain powers.

entry.def: See Koran.
